abstract: The European Championship has a history of underdog success stories, but a bonus automatic spot and a weighted playoff draw seem to put a thumb on the scale in favor of bigger nations.
snippet: The European Championship has a history of underdog success stories, but a bonus automatic spot and a weighted playoff draw seem to put a thumb on the scale in favor of bigger nations.
lead_paragraph: For a reason that has yet to be uncovered, UEFA's European Championship seems to routinely provide the stage for unfancied nations to upset the odds. Whether it was Denmark's triumph as a last-minute entry in 1992, Latvia's reaching the 2004 tournament at the expense of Turkey, whom it eliminated in the qualification playoffs, or Greece's triumph over Portugal in Lisbon in the same year, the Euros retain a shock quality that their more illustrious relative, the World Cup, often lacks.
